journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: Immersion- and invariance-based adaptive missile control using filtered signals

article-meta.aff: 1Division of Electronic Information and Communication, University of Kwandong, Gangwon, Republic of Korea
2Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Nevada Las Vegas, Las Vegas, Nevada, USA

author-notes.corresp: Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Nevada, Las Vegas, NV 89154, USA. email: sahaj@egr.unlv.edu

abstract.p: The article presents a new non-certainty-equivalent adaptive (NCEA) longitudinal autopilot for the control of a missile based on the immersion and invariance theory. The interest here is to control the angle of attack of the missile in the presence of large parametric uncertainties. For the derivation of the control law, a backstepping design procedure is used. At each step of the design, certain filtered signals are generated for the synthesis of a stabilizing control signal and a parameter estimator. Using Lyapunov stability analysis, it is shown that in the closed-loop system, trajectory control of the angle of attack is accomplished, and the trajectories of the system are attracted to certain manifold in the space of state variables and parameter errors. For stability in the closed-loop system, an explicit analytical relation involving the controller gains is obtained. It may be pointed out that recently an adaptive autopilot based on the immersion and inversion theory has been designed, but it has stringent requirements because for its synthesis, the derivatives of the Mach number and angle of attack must be known, and a large number of parameters must be updated. The derived control system of this article is synthesized using only the state variables, and its identifier is of lower order. A traditional certainty-equivalent adaptive autopilot is also presented for comparison. Simulation results are obtained which show that the designed NCEA control system can accomplish angle of attack control despite large parametric uncertainties; and it can give better tracking performance than the traditional controller.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Modern missiles are expected to operate over an expanded flight envelope to meet the challenge of highly manoeuvrable targets. The full envelope dynamics of missiles are non-linear and include wide variations in aerodynamic parameters. However, for simplicity, missile autopilots are often designed using linearized models. A comparison of classical designs and modern designs based on linear quadratic gaussian/loop transfer recovery (LQG/LTR) has been presented by Cloutier et al. [1] and Arrow and Williams [2]. Traditionally, for satisfactory performance over the flight envelope, gain-scheduled local autopilots are designed to yield a global controller [3–6]. Of course, gain scheduling methods ignore the actual non-linear behaviour of the system.

Linearized models cannot capture the dynamical behaviour of high-performance missiles operating in non-linear regime; and therefore for a satisfactory performance, autopilots must be designed based on the non-linear model. For non-linear missile models, authors have used input–output linearization (dynamic inversion) to design autopilots. In this method, the input–output map is linearized by coordinate transformation and non-linear feedback, and then linear design techniques are used to complete the derivation of the autopilot [7–10]. A discrete-time feedback linearization method has been also attempted for missile flight control [11]. However, dynamic inversion approach requires precise knowledge of system parameters. For the design of a robust missile autopilot, a combination of dynamic inversion and μ synthesis has been attempted [12]. The non-linear H∞ theory has been applied to missile with coupled aerodynamic and thrust-vectoring control [13]. For non-linear missile models, the state-dependent Riccati equation (SDRE) method, which is an extension of linear optimal control design method, has been proposed [14–15]; and longitudinal autopilot and hybrid bank-to-turn/skid-to-turn missile autopilot have been designed. In the SDRE method, non-linear model is represented as a linear-like system and pointwise solution of the Riccati equation is computed to obtain a suboptimal regulator. Since the design is based on the frozen system matrices, only local stability in the closed-loop system is assured. Recently, a new approach, termed θ − D technique, has been developed for designing non-linear autopilots. This method provides an approximate solution of the Hamilton–Jacobi Bellman equation for the synthesis of a suboptimal control law [16]. Based on the θ − D method, non-linear H∞ control of missile has been also treated [17].

For non-linear missile models with uncertain dynamics, variable structure (sliding mode) control systems have been designed [18–22]. The sliding mode control system is a discontinuous function of the state variables, and usually uses high gain feedback to dominate the uncertain functions. For large parametric uncertainties, adaptive design is preferred. Several adaptive laws for the control of missiles have been developed [23–26]. Using adaptive L1 theory, an autopilot for a missile using output feedback has been derived [25]. For missile models with unknown functions, adaptive neural controller design has been attempted [27, 28]. For neural control, unknown functions are linearly parameterized using basis functions, and then adaptation law is developed. These adaptive autopilots belong to a class of certainty-equivalent adaptive (CEA) systems, in which parameter estimates generated by update law are directly used for synthesis.

Recently, a new method for the design of adaptive control systems for uncertain non-linear systems, based on the immersion and invariance (I and I) theory, has been developed [29–31]. This approach gives a non-certainty-equivalent adaptive (NCEA) law. Unlike the CEA design method, the parameter estimator of the NCEA system provides an estimate of unknown parameter as a sum of a partial estimate generated by an update law and a judiciously chosen non-linear function. The non-linear function in the parameter estimate causes faster decay of the Lyapunov function. The essential idea of the I and I method is to create manifold in the extended space of state variables and partial parameter estimates to which trajectories are attracted. As the trajectory evolves on this manifold, the closed-loop system captures the behaviour of a target system, which can be obtained by synthesizing a full-information feedback (deterministic) control law. The I and I approach has been used to develop NCEA adaptive control systems for spacecraft, a multi-link manipulator and an aeroelastic system [32–34].

In a recent article, the design of an adaptive longitudinal autopilot based on the I and I theory has been attempted [35]. However, this control law requires not only the state variables but also the derivatives of the Mach number and the angle of attack for synthesis. This assumption of availability of derivatives is restrictive. Furthermore, for the synthesis of the control law, a large order parameter estimator must be constructed. In the derivation of the control law of reference [35], the derivatives of the Mach number and angle of attack have been used, so that the restriction posed by certain partial differential inequalities, arising in the I and I methodology, is avoided. These inequalities pose serious limitations on the applicability of the I and I method to practical problems. Recently, a new design method [32, 33] using filtered signals has been proposed to overcome the limitations of the I and I method [28–31]. For the derivation of control law in references [32–33], first filtered error dynamics are obtained, and then I and I method is applied. As such the design method using the filtered signals retains the special features of the I and I method. In view of the advantages of the NCEA laws, it is of interest to explore the applicability of the I and I method for the design of an autopilot, which uses only state variable feedback for controller synthesis.

The contribution of this article lies in the derivation of an NCEA longitudinal autopilot for the control of a missile based on the immersion and invariance theory. The mathematical model of the missile includes non-linearities, and it is assumed that the system parameters (except the sign of a single control input coefficient) are not known. The objective is to control the angle of the attack of the missile in the presence of large parametric uncertainties. Of course, an autopilot command logic can be used to convert commanded normal acceleration from the guidance laws to reference angle of attack commands for the autopilot. Such an approach has been also adopted in reference [16]. The design is performed using a simplified model of the missile by neglecting certain small input-dependent functions. For the simplified model, the angle of attack has relative degree two. For the control law derivation, a backstepping design procedure [36] is used. In order to avoid the difficulty posed by the partial differential inequalities of the I and I method, the tracking problem is transformed into a problem of regulator design for filtered error dynamics. At each step of the backstepping design, certain filters are introduced and stabilizing control signal and estimator are constructed. According to the I and I theory, each estimated parameter is chosen as the sum of a partial estimate generated by an update law and a non-linear function. Based on the Lyapunov stability analysis, it is shown that in the closed-loop system, trajectory tracking of the angle of attack is accomplished, and that the trajectories are attracted to a manifold in the space of the state variables and parameter errors. On this manifold, the NCEA law recovers the performance of a deterministic control system, designed for known parameters. This important feature of the NCEA law is not possible in CEA systems. For stability in the closed-loop system, an explicit analytical relation involving the controller gains is obtained. Unlike the I and I theory-based NCEA law for the missile control of reference [35], the control system designed in this article is synthesized using state variables; moreover, its parameter estimator is of relatively small order. It must be noted that parameter estimators of the NCEA systems have complicated structure and involve partial derivatives of non-linear functions. As such complexity of the estimator increases with number of unknown parameters. For the purpose of comparison, a traditional CEA law using backstepping procedure is also obtained. Simulation results using the NCEA and CEA laws are presented. These results show that in the complete closed-loop system, including the input-dependent terms of the model, which are ignored for simplicity in design, the NCEA autopilot accomplishes angle of attack trajectory control, despite large uncertainties in the aerodynamic parameters. These results also show that for properly chosen feedback and adaptation gains, the tracking error control performance of the NCEA law is better than the CEA law.

sec.title: 2 MISSILE LONGITUDINAL DYNAMICS
sec.p:
The pitch-plane rigid missile model considered here has two translational degrees of freedom and one rotational degree of freedom. Figure 1 illustrates the coordinate system and variables used for describing the longitudinal dynamics of the missile. U and W are the components of the velocity vector VT along the body-fixed X and Z axes, L the aerodynamic lift, D the drag, and MY the pitching moment. Fig. 1
Missile coordinate system

The mathematical model used in this article is based on a tail-controlled missile. This model assumes constant mass, that is, post burnout, zero roll angle and roll rate, no sideslip, and zero yaw rate. Under these assumptions, the motion of the missile is described by two force equations and one kinematic equation. Readers may refer to reference [14] for the details. These non-linear differential equations describing the evolution of the Mach number (M), angle of attack (α), pitch rate (Q), and pitch angle (θ) are [14] (1) where tan α = (W/U), M=(U2+W2)/a, a is the speed of sound, γ = θ − α the flight path angle, P0 the static pressure, IY the moment of inertia, m the mass, S the reference area, g the gravity, and CD0, CN, and Cm the non-dimensional aerodynamic coefficients. For the missile at 20 000 ft altitude, the aerodynamic coefficients are
where δ is the control surface deflection and ak, bk, dk, and ek the constant parameters. The aerodynamic coefficients and the physical parameters of the missile provided in reference [14] are collected in Tables 1 and 2, respectively. Table 1
Aerodynamic polynomial coefficients
Normal force Pitch moment
an = 19.373 am = 40.440
bn = −31.023 bm = −64.015
cn = −9.717 cm = 2.922
dn = −1.948 dm = −11.803
CD0 = .300 em = −1.719
Table 2
Physical characteristics
Symbol Name Value
P0 Static pressure 973.3 lb/ft2
IY Moment of inertia 182.5 slug-ft2
S Reference area 0.44 ft2
d Reference distance 0.75 ft
m Mass 13.98 slug
a Speed of sound 1,036.4 ft/s
g Gravity 32.2 ft/s2

For these mass properties and the aerodynamic coefficients, the dynamic equations are given by [14] (2) (3) (4) where T denotes matrix transposition, b01 = −0.0403, r1 = −0.0062, b02 = −0.0403, b03 = −14.54, the regressor vectors are
and the parameter vectors are

Defining the state vector x = (α, M, Q, θ)T ∈ R4, a state variable form of the missile's longitudinal dynamics can be written as (5) It is assumed that all the parameter vectors pk (k = 1, 2, 3), as well as the scalar parameters r1, b01 and b02 are unknown, but for the derivation of the control law, an assumption is made.

statement.title: Assumption 1
statement.p: The magnitude of b03 is unknown, but its sign is known.

sec.p: The objective here is to control the angle of attack (α) of the missile so that it follows prescribed reference angle of attack trajectory (αr). Because the system parameters are not known, we are interested in developing a non-linear adaptive autopilot, and synthesizing the controller using only the state variables.

sec.title: 3 ADAPTIVE CONTROL LAW DESIGN
sec.p: In this section, the design of NCEA control system based on the I and I theory is considered. A backstepping design procedure is used for the derivation of the stabilizing signal and the estimator at each step. Backstepping is a non-linear control design technique that employs Lyapunov synthesis to recursively determine the controller [36]. According to the I and I theory, the estimator provides an estimate of each parameter that is a sum of a partial estimate generated by an update law and a non-linear function.

For the derivation of the control law, the angle of attack is treated as an output variable. The number of steps required for completing the design using backstepping depends on the relative degree of α. The relative degree of α is the least integer r such that drα/dtr depends on the input δ. It may be pointed out that the tail fin is principally a moment producing device, but it also produces small control forces. It is seen that for the complete missile model including the δ-dependent term in equation (2), the relative degree is one, and the control input gain is b01 M cos α. For a controlled missile, it is known that δ-dependent term in α· equation causes non-minimum phase dynamic behaviour which can give rise to instability [11, 37]. For avoiding non-minimum phase responses, feedback linearizing control laws for missiles and aircraft have been derived using simplified models obtained by ignoring small control forces [7, 9, 11, 38]. Note that if b01 and b02 are set to zero, then the relative degree of α is two, and the control input gain b03M2 for feedback linearization is large compared to the input gain for the model with b01 ≠ 0. As such the control moment is more suitable for changing the angle of attack. Therefore, for the purpose of control law derivation, a simplified model obtained by neglecting the δ-dependent terms in the derivative of α and M will be used.

Define a new input u related to δ as
By setting b01 and b02 to zero, the simplified model obtained from equation (5) is given by (6) where b = |b03| > 0. (Often the arguments of variables will be suppressed for simplicity.) Since for the simplified model, the relative degree of α is two, the design will be completed in two steps.

Step 1: Let α~=α-αr be the tracking error. Its derivative is (7) We introduce a coordinate change defined by Q~=Q-Qc, where Qc is a stabilizing control signal, yet to be determined. Then, one can write equation (7) as (8)

To this end, first-order filters are introduced and each of the signals ϕ1, Q, Qc, α, and αr are filtered. The filtered signals are governed by the following differential equations (9) where λ > 0, and the variables with subscript f denote filtered signals. (It will be seen later that the filter used for Qcf is only for analysis and will not be used for the implementation of control law.) Each filtered signal can be treated as an output of a first-order filter (10) where s denotes the Laplace variable (or a derivative operator) and G(s) the transfer function. It will be seen that introduction of the filters simplifies derivation of the NCEA law, and one does not encounter any partial differential inequalities of the original I and I method in references [29–31].

Filtering each function in equation (8) through G(s) gives (11) where Q~f=Qf-Qcf and α~f=αf-αrf. One may note that exponentially decaying signals due to initial conditions have been ignored in equation (11), because for asymptotic analysis these signals are not important. The objective is to regulate the filtered tracking error by the control signal Qcf. Of course, if α~f is zero, then in view of equation (9), α~ will asymptotically converge to zero.

The parameter vector p1 in equation (11) is not known. As such it is essential to obtain an estimate of p1 ∈ R4. Let an estimate of p1 be p∧1+μ1(α~f,φ1f), where μ1 ∈ R4 is an appropriate non-linear vector function yet to be determined. (The choice of the arguments of μ1 will be justified later.) We treat p∧1 as a partial estimate and full estimate is obtained by adding μ1 to p∧1. The partial estimate p∧1 will be generated by an adaptation law. Then, the parameter error is (12)

Now for eliminating the known and estimated functions in equation (11), the stabilizing signal Qcf is chosen as (13) where k1 > 0 is a design parameter. Substituting the control law equation (13) in (11) gives (14)

To this end, an estimator is designed. For its design, one must determine an update law for p∧1 as well as the function μ1. Differentiating z1 in equation (12) and using equation (14) gives the parameter error dynamics of the form (15) In order to obtain a stable behaviour of z1, in view of equation (15), one selects the adaptation law for p∧1 of the form (16) Note that in equation (15), φ·1f is substituted using equation (9).

Substituting equation (16) in (15) gives (17) In order to make the coefficient of z1 negative, one sets the partial derivative of μ1 as (18) where γ1 > 0 is the adaptation gain. Then, the parameter error dynamics become (19) Note that ϕ1f is a state vector satisfying (9); and therefore it is not an explicit function of α~f. Integrating equation (18) with respect to α~f yields the non-linear function (20) The partial derivative of μ1 with respect to ϕ1f is (21) where I4×4 denotes a 4 × 4 identity matrix. Substituting these partial derivatives in equation (16) and using φ·1f from equation (9), gives the adaptation law in a simplified form as (22)

To examine the asymptotic behaviour of α~f and z1, consider a Lyapunov function (23) where η1 is a positive number. Its derivative along the solution of equations (14) and (19) is (24) From equation (24), one obtains (25) where the matrix L1 is
Since V1 is a positive definite function of α~f and z1, in view of equation (25), (α~f,z1) will be bounded if L1 is a positive definite matrix and Q~f is zero. But Qf is a state variable, and it cannot be chosen equal to Qcf. In step 2 of the design process, the function α~fQ~f appearing in equation (25) will be compensated and certain negative functions will dominate the remaining positive terms of equation (25).

To this end, it is essential to compute Qc, which is the input to the filter generating Qcf. From equation (9), one finds that (26) Using the expression for Qcf from equation (13), one has (27) Collecting terms in equation (27) gives (28) One notes from the filter equation (9) that φ·1f+λφ1f=φ1, α~·f+λα~f=α~, and (29) Using these equations, equation (28) can be written in a simple form as (30) Using the derivatives of p∧1 from equation (22) and μ1=γ1α~fφ1f, and the filter equation (9), one can show that (31) Substituting equation (31) in equation (30) gives the stabilizing signal (32) This completes step 1.

Step 2: Now the control input u (i.e. δ) must be chosen so that Q~f tends to zero. For this, the dynamics of Q~f must be obtained. The derivative of Qc can be obtained by differentiating the expression for Qc given in equation (32). (The derivation for Q·c is provided in Appendix 2.) The expression for Q·c is (33) where ps=[p1 T,r1]T∈R5 is the vector of unknown parameters and the non-linear functions ψs ∈ R5, ψ2, and ψ0 are given in Appendix 2.

Differentiating Q~ and using equations (6) and (33) gives (34) Adding and subtracting α~ and k2Q~ and factoring b, one write equation (34) as (35) where k2 > 0. Collecting terms in equation (35) gives (36) where p5=b-1[p3 T,ps T,1]T∈R10 is the vector of unknown parameters, and the non-linear regressor vector is (37)

Similar to step 1, consider filtered signals uf and ϕ5f satisfying the differential equations (38) It is pointed out that the filter to generate uf is introduced here only for the purpose of control law derivation, and it will not be needed for synthesis. Filtering both sides of equation (36) through G(s) gives (39) Let an estimate of the unknown parameter vector p5 be p∧5+μ2(Q~f,φ5f). Then, the parameter error z2 is (40) In view of equation (39), for ensuring stability of the Q~ dynamics, a control law is selected (41) which can be substituted in equation (39) to give (42)

Now, the design of the identifier is considered. Differentiating z2 in equation (40) and using equation (42) give the dynamics of the parameter error vector of the form (43) In view of equation (43), one can select the update law for p∧5 as (44) Substituting the derivative of p∧5 in equation (43), one obtains the dynamics of the parameter error given by (45) For obtaining a stable behaviour of z2, one selects (46) where γ2 > 0 is an adaptation gain. It is noted that ϕ5f is a state vector satisfying equation (38); and therefore, it is not a function of Q~f. Integrating equation (46) with respect to Q~f gives the non-linear vector function (47) Substituting the partial derivatives of μ2 with respect to Q~f and ϕ5f in equation (44) and using equation (38) for φ·5f give the adaptation law and ż2 of the form (48) Using μ2 from equation (47) in equation (41), one obtains the control input uf given by (49)
Now based on these results, the following theorem is stated.

statement.title: Theorem 1
statement.p: Consider the closed-loop system (6) including the control and adaptation laws (49), (22), and (48). Then, in the closed-loop system, Q~f, φ1f Tz1, φ5f Tz2 and the tracking error α~ asymptotically tend to zero.

sec.p: (For a proof, see Appendix 2.)

For the synthesis of controller, the signal u remains to be computed. Using equation (38), one has (50) Using equations (38) and (48) and the derivative of μ2 (equation (47)), one can show that (51) (The derivation of control input u is given in Appendix 2.)

statement.title: Remark 1
statement.p:
In the closed-loop system, the non-linear functions φ1f Tz1 and φ5f Tz2 asymptotically converge to zero. As such, the manifold defined by (52) where
is indeed an attractive manifold. Along any trajectory evolving on Ω, the dynamics of α~f (equation (14)) and Q~f (equation (42)) take a simple form given by (53) Apparently, equation (53) can be obtained if one implements a control law designed based on the missile model with known parameters. As such the NCEA law indeed recovers the performance of a deterministic control system. It is easily seen that from equation (53) that
which implies that α~f and Q~f will tend to zero, as expected.

statement.title: Remark 2
statement.p: In view of equation (48), the equilibrium point z2 = 0 is globally stable. This is easily verified using a positive definite Lyapunov function (z2 Tz2), which yields d(z2 Tz2)/dt=-bγ1(Φ5f Tz2)2≤0.

sec.p: It is pointed out that this I and I-based NCEA control system design process using filtered signals can be extended to systems for which the controlled output variable has relative degree larger than two. At each step, filters are introduced, stabilizer and estimator are derived, and at the final step control input is obtained.

To this end, a discussion related to implementation issue for the NCEA law is provided. First, it is noted that although analytical derivation of the NCEA law is somewhat involved, the final expressions for the stabilizing signal Qc (equation (32) and control input u (equation (51)) are simple. Only filtered signals needed for synthesis are αf, Qf, αrf, ϕ1f, and ϕ5f. These signals are obtained by filtering α, Q, αr and regressors ϕ1, and ϕ5 through the first-order filter G(s). The filtered signal uf is not needed for synthesis. The filtered signal Qcf is already known from equation (13); and therefore, one does not need to filter Qc to get Qcf. The update laws for p∧1 and p∧5 are given in equations (22) and (48).

sec.title: 4 CEA LAW
sec.p: For the purpose of comparison, a CEA law is briefly derived. Again for the derivation, the backstepping procedure of previous section is used. However, for the CEA law, it is not necessary to use filtered signals. For the NCEA system, filters were used to overcome the limitation of the I and I method. As such filters are not used and a simpler CEA law is derived.

Step 1 : We begin with equation (8) which is (54) The stabilising signal Qc is selected as (55) where p∧1 is an estimate of p1. Let z1=p∧1-p1 be the parameter error. (The symbols used in this section should be not be confused with those used in the previous section.) Note that for the CEA law, non-linear functions μi are set to zero. Then, one has the tracking error dynamics given by (56)

Consider a Lyapunov function (57) Its derivative along the solution of equation (56) is (58) For cancelling the unknown term in equation (58), the update law is chosen as (59) Substituting equation (59) in equation (58) yields (60) The Q~-dependent term is compensated in step 2.

Step 2 : Now stabilization of the dynamics of Q~ is considered. The derivative of Qc is (61) where the functions ψk are defined in equation (61). (Note that these functions (ψi) are different from those of Appendix 2, defined for the NCEA law.) Substituting M· and α· from equation (6) gives (62) where ps ∈ R5 and ψs ∈ R5 are defined in equation (62).

Using equation (62), the dynamics of Q~ takes the form (63) where p5 ∈ R10 is the vector of unknown parameters and ϕ5 ∈ R10 the regressor. In view of equation (63), we select the control input as (64) where p∧5, is an estimate of p5 and z2=p∧5-p5 the parameter error. Substituting equation (64) in equation (63) gives (65)

For examining stability in the closed-loop system, consider a composite Lyapunov function (66) Differentiating V and using equations (60) and (65), one has (67) In view of equation (67), one chooses the update law for p∧5 given by (68) which is substituted in equation (67) to yield (69)

The Lyapunov function V is a positive definite function of α~,Q~,z1,z2, and V·≤0. Using arguments similar to those of the NCEA law, one can establish boundedness of signals and convergence of the tracking error α~ and Q~ to zero.

To this end, based on the derivation of the previous sections, the special features of the NCEA law are summarized and the differences in the NCEA and CEA laws are pointed out. The special features of the NCEA system are: (i) the estimated parameter vectors in equations (12) and (40) are the sum of p∧i and a non-linear function μk, (ii) the derivative of the Lyapunov function includes quadratic functions of φif Tzk (equation (74)), (iii) there exists a manifold Ω to which the trajectories of the closed-loop system are attracted (Remark 1, equation (52)), (iv) the NCEA law asymptotically recovers the performance of a deterministic controller (Remark 1, equation (53)), and (v) the equilibrium point z2 = 0 is globally stable (Remark 2). It is seen, in Section 4, that the CEA law does not have these features. In the next section, it will be seen that the NCEA law gives better tracking performance than the CEA law.

Now, the differences in the adaptive controllers of this article and those of reference [35] are indicated. First of all, unlike the design method of [35], here the control laws have been derived using a backstepping design procedure. Furthermore, unlike the NCEA law of [35], filtered signals are used here for synthesis. It is noted that due to introduction of filtered signals in each step of design, the details in the derivation of this controller differ from the backstepping design of reference [36], which does not use filtered signals for synthesis. The dimension of the estimated parameter vector for the NCEA and CEA laws in this article is 14, but reference [35] uses 27 estimated parameters for synthesis. As such the adaptation law of this article is relatively simple. Most importantly, the NCEA and CEA laws of this article are synthesised using only the state variables. However, the NCEA law of reference [35] requires measurement of the state variables as well as the derivatives of the angle of attack and Mach number for feedback. The CEA law of reference [35] needs the state variables and α· for synthesis.

sec.title: 5 SIMULATION RESULTS
sec.p: This section presents results of digital simulation for the closed-loop systems using the NCEA and CEA laws. The model parameters of reference [14] are used for computation. Although the simplified model has been used for the control law design, the complete model equation (5), including the δ-dependent functions in α· and M·, is simulated for the control law evaluation, i.e. b10 and b20 are non-zero. The initial value of the state vector is x(0) = [0, 2.5, 0, 0]T. The value of λ used in the filter is 1, and the initial conditions for the scalar signals αf(0), Qf(0), and αrf(0) and the regressor vectors ϕ1f(0), and ϕ5f(0) are set to zero. The adaptation gains chosen are γ1 = 10, γ2 = 2, and the feedback gains are k1 = 3 and k2 = 8.

The initial conditions for p∧i(0) (i = 1, 5) are assumed to be zero (for Cases A–D) and 0.5 pi (for Case E). For the choice of zero initial conditions, one has 100 per cent uncertainty in each parameter vector p1 and p5. Of course, the transient responses depend on the choice of the initial values of p∧i(0), since the estimated parameters generated by the update law are used for the synthesis of the control law (51). It is pointed out that the closed-loop adaptive system is a non-linear time-varying system; and therefore, it is difficult to predict the effect of choice of initial estimates p∧i(0) on the transient responses of the missile model with uncertain parameters. However, the designed NCEA law ensures asymptotic tracking even for arbitrary large parameter variations.

A fourth-order command generator of the form
is chosen where ζ1 = 1, ζ2 = 1 and αr * is the angle of attack command. For slow command, ωi = 3 and for fast command, ωi = 5 are chosen (i = 1, 2). A piecewise constant command (in degrees) is (αr *(t)=5 for t ∈ [0, ts) and αr *(t)=0 for t ≥ ts) or (αr *(t)=10 for t ∈ [0, ts) and αr *(t)=0 for t ≥ ts), where ts = 3 (s) is the switching time.
Case A. Adaptive control with slow and small αr commands: ω1= ω2 = 3, αr *∈{5,0} (degree)

For the control of the missile, the NCEA law equation (51) is implemented. A slow command input αr *(t)=5 for t ∈ [0, 3) and αr *=0 for t ∈ [3, 10) is applied. The initial estimates of the parameters are p∧i(0)=0. The selected responses for the NCEA law are shown in Fig. 2(a) to (h). It is observed that α follows the reference trajectory (αr) closely; and the terminal error α~ is almost zero (−0.0004°) at 10 s. The peak value of the tracking error is less than 0.4° (Fig. 2(d)), which is quite small. The peak value of the control input required is 18.25° (Fig. 2(e)). The estimated parameters p∧1+μ1 and p∧5+μ2 converge to some constant values, and the system's trajectory converges to the manifold Ω defined by φ1f Tz1=0 and φ5f Tz2=0. Therefore, as indicated in Remark 1, the NCEA law recovers the performance of the deterministic controller. Fig. 2
Adaptive control for slow and small αr command: ζ1 = 1, ζ2 = 1, ω1 = 3, ω2 = 3, αr* ∈ {5, 0} (degree); (a) α (degree) and reference αr (degree); (b) M; (c) Q (degree/s); (d) Tracking error α~ (degree); (e) δ (degree); (f) θ (degree); (g) Parameter estimates : norm of p∧1+μ1 and p∧5+μ2; (h) φ1f Tz1 and φ5f Tz2

Simulation is also performed using the CEA law equation (64). For a fair comparison, the controller gains (k1, k2) and adaptation gains (γ1, γ2) of the NCEA law are used for the CEA law. Furthermore, the initial conditions used for the NCEA law are retained. The closed-loop responses including the CEA law for the identical command input are shown in Fig. 2. It is seen that although the angle of attack follows the reference trajectory, the maximum tracking error (1.27°) and the terminal error (−0.1578°) for the CEA system are larger than those of the NCEA system. The peak value of control input required is 19.4°, which is about 1° larger than that of the NCEA system. The estimated parameters p∧1 and p∧5 of the CEA system also converge to some constant values. (The plots of the estimated parameters for the CEA system are not shown here.)
Case B. Adaptive control for fast but small αr command: ω1 = ω2 = 5, αr *∈{5,0} (degree)

A fast reference trajectory is generated by setting ω1 = ω2 = 5 in the command generator, but the command input αr * of Fig. 2 is used. The remaining parameters of the control system used for Fig. 2 are retained. Figure 3 shows the responses of the NCEA and CEA systems. It is observed that α tracks αr and converges almost to zero (−0.0001°) for the NCEA system, but again the CEA system has larger error (−0.1277°) at 10 s. The peak values of the tracking errors for the NCEA and CEA laws are 0.9248° and 1.6231°, respectively. Again, it is observed that φ1f Tz1 and φ5f Tz2 tend to be zero. The maximum control magnitude for the NCEA and CEA laws are 19.3353° and 20.1400°, respectively. Only a minor difference in the peak values of δ is observed. Fig. 3
Adaptive control for fast but small αr command : ζ1 = 1, ζ2 = 1, ω1 = 5, ω2 = 5, αr* ∈ {5, 0} (degree); (a) α (degree) and reference αr (degree); (b) M; (c) Q (degree/s) (d) Tracking error α~ (degree); (e) δ (degree); (f) θ (degree); (g) Parameter estimates : norm of p∧1+μ1 and p∧5+μ2; (h) φ1f Tz1 and φ5f Tz2
Case C. Adaptive control for slow but large αr command: ω1 =ω2 = 3, αr *∈{10,0} (degree)

Now, simulation is done for a larger angle of attack control. For this, the command input is αr *(t)=10 for t ∈ [0, 3), and then αr *(t)=0 for t ≥ 3. Again, the command input switches from 10° to 0° at 3 s. The poles of the command generator are at −3. Selected responses for the NCEA and CEA systems are shown in Fig. 4. It is seen that for the NCEA system, the angle of attack follows αr closely and converges to a very small value (−0.0012°), but for the CEA law, it converges to a larger value −0.1475° at the terminal time 10 s. The peak value of the tracking error and the control input δ for the NCEA and CEA laws are (0.7722, 40.6121) (degree) and (1.6712, 40.4100) (deg), respectively. It is seen that for large command, both the NCEA and CEA laws require large control inputs as expected compared to those shown in Fig. 2. The peak value of tracking error for the CEA system is larger than that of the NCEA law. Again, the system trajectory tends to the manifold Ω. Fig. 4
Adaptive control for slow but large αr command : ζ1 = 1, ζ2 = 1, ω1 = 3, ω2 = 3, αr* ∈ {10, 0} (degree); (a) α (degree) and reference αr (degree); (b) M; (c) Q (degree/s); (d) Tracking error α~ (degree); (e) δ (degree); (f) θ (degree); (g) Parameter estimates : norm of p∧1+μ1 and p∧5+μ2; (h) φ1f Tz1 and φ5f Tz2
Case D. Adaptive control for fast and large αr command: ω1 = ω2 = 5, αr *∈{10,0} (degree)

Simulation is done for 10° angle of attack control using the fast command input (ωi = 5). Figure 5 shows the responses obtained with the NCEA and CEA laws. It is observed that both the NCEA and CEA systems accomplished trajectory tracking, but the terminal error (−0.119°) for the CEA law is larger than the error (−0.0004°) for the NCEA law. The peak values of the tracking error and the control magnitude for the NCEA and CEA laws are (1.4197, 41.7178) (degree) and (1.9723, 41.7366) (degree), respectively. It is seen that even though the command trajectory is fast, the peak values of the control input are close to those of Fig. 4. The maximum tracking error for the NCEA system is again smaller compared to the error obtained with the CEA law. Again, it is observed that φ1f Tz1 and φ5f Tz2 tend to zero, therefore, the closed-loop trajectory converges to the manifold Ω. The peak values of the control inputs for the NCEA and CEA laws are nearly the same. Fig. 5
Adaptive control for fast and large αr command: ζ1 = 1, ζ2 = 1, ω1 = 5, ω2 = 5, αr* ∈ {10, 0} (degree); (a) α (degree) and reference αr (degree); (b) M; (c) Q (degree/s); (d) Tracking error α~ (degree); (e) δ (degree); (f) θ (degree); (g) Parameter estimates : norm of p∧1+μ1 and p∧5+μ2; (h) φ1f Tz1 and φ5f Tz2
Case E. Adaptive control for fast and large αr command: uncertainty 50 per cent, ω1 = ω2 = 5, αr *∈{10,0} (degree)

For examining the effect of choice of initial estimates, simulation is done using p∧i(0)=0.5pi, i = 1, 5. The controller parameters of Case D are retained. Selected responses are shown in Fig. 6. Smooth convergence of the tracking error is observed. The peak values of the tracking error and the control magnitude for the NCEA and CEA laws are (1.0291, 41.6727) (degree) and (1.3430, 43.0215) (degree), respectively. It is observed that peak values of the error and control input of Case E for the NCEA law are only slightly smaller than those of Case D for 100 per cent uncertainty with the NCEA law. The estimated parameters show small changes because the uncertainty in the parameter vector is smaller (50 per cent) in this case. Simulation results for other off-nominal parameters also show trajectory control of α. Fig. 6
Adaptive control for fast and large αr command: 50% uncertainty, ζ1 = 1, ζ2 = 1, ω1 = 5, ω2 = 5, αr* ∈ {10, 0} (degree); (a) α (degree) and reference αr (degree); (b) φ1f Tz1 and φ5f Tz2; (c) Q (degree/s); (d) Tracking error α~ (degree); (e) δ (degree); (f) θ (degree); (g) Parameter estimates : norm of p∧1+μ1; (h) Parameter estimates : norm of p∧5+μ2

These results show that the NCEA system gives better tracking performance compared to the CEA system. For the choice of identical values of the feedback gains, the maximum and terminal tracking errors of the NCEA system are smaller than those of the CEA system. In fact, the terminal error of the NCEA system is almost zero. However, by simulation, it has been found that the tracking performance of the CEA law can be improved if large controller gains are used. For example, with large values (γi = 20, k1 = 30, k2 = 80, λ = 80), the peak value of tracking error for the CEA law for 5° slow command of Case A is 0.027°. Of course, choice of large gains defeats the purpose of adaptive systems; and moreover, large gains are not preferred for practical reasons. Of course, the special feature of the NCEA law, related to performance recovery (Remark 1) is not possible in the CEA systems.

To this end, results of this article are compared with those of reference [35] designed using I and I method. In a qualitative sense, the convergence property of the closed-loop system including the state variable feedback NCEA law of this article is similar to that of reference [35]. However, it should be noted that the NCEA law of reference [35] uses α· and M· besides the state variables for synthesis, and includes adaptation law for estimating larger number of parameters (27 instead of 14). Of course, the numerical values of the responses depend on the choice of controller parameters.

sec.title: 6 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: In this article, based on the immersion and invariance theory, a new NCEA longitudinal autopilot for control of a missile using state feedback was designed. A backstepping design process was used for completing the design in two steps. At each step, certain filtered signals were introduced to overcome the restrictions posed by the partial differential inequalities, which arise in the original immersion and invariance method. At each step of design, stabilising signal and estimator were derived separately. Unlike the CEA systems, each estimated parameter was formed by summing an estimate provided by an update law and a non-linear function. Based on the Lyapunov analysis, trajectory control of the angle of attack was established. A traditional certainty-equivalent control system was also designed. It was also shown that unlike the CEA controllers, the NCEA law accomplished regulation of the trajectories to a manifold on which the system recovered the performance of the deterministic controller. Simulation results showed accurate tracking of the angle of attack in spite of large parameter uncertainties. It was seen that for properly chosen feedback and adaptation gains, the NCEA controller gave a better tracking error control performance than the CEA controller.

sec.title: Q·c, Proof of Theorem 1 and u for NCEA law
Derivation of Q·c

sec.title: Proof of Theorem 1
sec.p:
To examine stability in the closed-loop system, consider a composite Lyapunov function V = V1 + V2, where (70) and η2 > 0. Differentiating V2 and using equations (42) and (48) give (71) Using Young's inequality gives
where ϵ > 0 is a positive number. Using this inequality in equation (71) gives (72) Let η2 be chosen such that η2γ2≥η3+14ε for some η3 > 0. Then, equation (72) gives (73)

Now, the stability property of the closed-loop system can be examined using the derivative of the composite Lyapunov function V. Using equations (25) and (73) gives the derivative of V of the form (74) where the matrix L2 is

V is a positive definite function of α~f, Q~f, φ1f Tz1, and φ5f Tz2. According to equation (74), V·≤0 if L2 is a positive definite matrix (denoted as L2 > 0). Of course, there exist parameters of the controller for which L2 is positive definite. (Later, it will be shown that L2 > 0.) Therefore, in view of equation (74), one finds that (α~f, Q~f, φ1f Tz1, φ5f Tz2)∈L∞[0,∞) (the set of bounded functions). Integrating equation (74), it is seen that α~f, Q~f, φ1f Tz1, and φ5f Tz2 are square integrable functions. Under assumption of post-burnout model, M is bounded; and therefore, ϕ1 and Qcf (given in equation (13)) and Qc are bounded. This implies that Q and Qf are bounded; and the input and outputs signals of all the filters are bounded. Since the derivatives of α~f, Q~f, φ1f Tz1, and φ5f Tz2 are also bounded, it follows that these signals converge to zero. Of course, if α~f tends to zero, then the tracking error (α~) must converge to zero.
The matrix L2 is positive definite, if k2 − ϵ > 0 and the determinant of L2 is positive. Computing the determinant of L gives

where k¯2=k2-ε. The polynomial f(η1) has two positive roots η1a and η1b (η1a < η1b) if
or equivalently (75) It is apparent in view of the form of f(η1) that if k1k¯2>(1/4), then for any value of η1 ∈ (η1a, η1b), the determinant of L2 is positive. This establishes existence of the parameters η1, η2, and ϵ for the stability in the system. Of course, the values of these are not needed for controller synthesis.
